text:
Translator: Robert Tucker
Reviewer: Nadine Hennig
Klaus Reichert: I'm already very excited.

We have invited Matze B.,
Matthias Brenner, here from Kreuzlingen,

whom I would like
to warmly welcome to the stage.
(Applause)
Matze B.: Okay.

So, first of all, I'm sorry
that I'm the only one here
not to speak with a fancy headset.
There's a simple reason for that:

Since my texts mostly have
a dynamic that bursts out a little,
I need to have the possibility
to draw back with my voice.

I thought, even though
it's getting towards the end,

I'd start with a little
get-to-know-you game.
I learnt it during a management workshop.
It's very simple.

I count to three, and then everyone
says their name, okay?
Right, so: one, two, three: Matze.
Great.
So now we know each other, we can start.
Well, I'm no businessman,
at least not a successful one.
(Laughter)

I'm also not a visionary
in any strict sense of the term.
I've no big idea

with which to make
the world a better place.
And naturally TED[x] attendees here
will be asking two questions:
Why him?
And what the hell is a poetry slam?

I will try to briefly answer
the second question,

or if possible, answer so that the first
question is maybe forgotten.
A poetry slam is a modern poetry contest,

it was started in the 80s in Chicago
by Mark Kelley Smith,
a former builder or draughtsman.
He couldn't accept the fact

that poetry, poems, lyrics,
spoken literature

are only performed
in a 'water-glass reading' scenario:

A table, an older gentleman
and a glass of water, and then,

"I will read from my cycle 'Blue'
the fifth poem 'Cobalt'."
He wanted to get away from that,
and said, "'We need slam poetry."
"Slam", a term used in sport;

it should be zappy, it should be punchy,
it should cut through.

We want it removed
from ivory tower posturing
and the "I'm an intellectual."
We'll do it in local clubs, squats,

on the road, no matter where -
somewhere where things move.
And that was the idea.

Something very central to poetry slam:
there's no expert jury.

So it's not like X-Factor
or Britain's Got Talent,

where they have experts
saying things like,
"I'm not sure about that.

You didn't get the iambs
in the third line quite right,"

but rather the audience,
the people listening, are the jury.
The audience form an unelected jury,

and they get a scoreboard
like in figure skating.
A ten is for a poem

that triggers a spontaneous
collective orgasm in the room,
and a zero is for a poem
that should never have been written.
You got the verb tense. Right?
So that's how slam started,
and there are only token prizes.

There's really nothing to win,
except a bottle of rum and some honor,

or a whisky and knock it back,
as is more usually the case.

You just get a bottle
of whisky, and that's it.
There are three rules in poetry slam,
and they're quite simple.
The first rule is:
it must be a self-written text.
The choice of genre is totally free.
That's something I really like about slam.

You're not tied
to any particular text form.

You can recite whatever you want
as long as it's your own work.
So I can't recite the work of another poet

like Schiller, Schwitters,
or Tupac Shakur;
it must be mine.
The second rule is: no props.
I think I'm obeying that today.

So no props, no costumes,
no masks, no instruments,
no animals or relatives on stage.

There should ultimately really
just be the poet, his text,

the written script
and the microphone there.
And the third rule
- and this one is much like with TED[x] -
is that there is a time limit.
The texts are normally limited
to somewhere between five and ten minutes.
Five minutes, so doing the maths,
it means I can do three texts.
So, enough to put me to the test.

Right, that's all about slam,
that was slam.
What's actually really important -

or what's really important
for me personally
is the cathartic experience,

the direct communication
with the audience.
I really do get an instant reply,

and sometimes it's not
so nice, on the stage.

Here in Konstanz,
where I started slamming,
the audience is particularly well known
to be very frank with you.

So if someone starts getting bored,
they start snapping their fingers,
and that can really get on your nerves,
or they yell, boo, and so on.

So all sorts of positive
and negative reaction.

The advantage for me as a poet
is really that I have direct feedback:

What's the problem? How can I change it?
How can I work on the text?

So, some introductory words on:
What is poetry slam?

Perhaps with the 'E' in TED,
'entertainment',
is where I fit in a bit.

So I'd like to start very briefly
with my first text.
It is a very short text,

it's to do with my part
of the country, my origins.
It goes like this:
(South German dialect) No.
No, I'm not from here.
Well, where are you from then?

(Standard German) Well, I'm
the son of my father.
(South German Dialect)Yeah, of my father,

the son of Ernst Brenner,
Bernhard Brenner, his lad.
Oh, yes; you've grown.

(Standard German) Talk tends to go
something like that back home in Nagold.

Today, it's clear to me
why I started to read.

Nagold, oh woody village,
your meadows of never lusher field,
where birds sing and flowers upward yield,

where the Bambi deer
are by hunters keeled,

and the ground shakes
as field guns fire zealed.
Here, I wish to die, but never live.
Just a short idea of how it goes.
(Applause)
Thank you, thank you.
So that was about my part of the country,
my origin in Nagold - beautiful.
Perhaps you'll come by one day.

Right, the second text
that I've prepared for you
is perhaps my only, my greatest -
my only hit.

And it deals with what
I think, many students

there will be many people among you
who need to write on the computer
who will know the problem.
The text is called:
"Ten-
Finger-
Typing-
Fuck."
The spiri-t
of people has mos-t
the body as its limi-t.
And no matter how in the figh-t

the genie us with whip
has stripe-d and spike-d
us to take flight,
the body has remaine-d chaine-d
fatefully to the realities of life.
I'm too weak, too awkward, too clumsy
to escape the Earthly pull.
The body is feeble, but the mind is alert.
And recently I found the solution
to nonetheless overcome the dilemma,
because I now know ten-finger typing.

I can type ten times more,
tippity-tap-tap-tap-tap,

with a light, nimble finger dance
that's really fast.
Now I've got it off, I rattle away,
as on my typewriter time slips by.
Ratch! New sheet. Datch!
Comma comma, comma comma, comma commedia.
Tap, tap, stop, stop, ssh-shting.
My problem no more.

Ten times faster, ten times, ten times
ten times more paper I need.
I now write ten po-e-ms in ten seconds

and ten e-pics, text e-pisodes,
if only the "e" wouldn't always sti-ck.
Time's no problem when I write now,

because now I've found it,
and know ten-finger typing,
space and time seem overcome.

I can now take a drag
on ten cigarettes at a time,

because I can, with
with ten fingers dog-ends flick,
and with ten fingertips fags fiddle.
Casually give a lady a light,
because now I can flick ten lighters;
ten flickering flames shield.

With ten quivering tongues of fire
magic up ten flaming punches,
ten fizzling matches snap.

Can torture TV channels
while watching, avoid advertising
Because I can now with my ten fingers zap.

Tippity- tip-tip-tip;
see there's quiet all round.

And when I fire up,
using Netscape perhaps,
there is now yet another escape,

for I can now double, double-click
ten times, ten times faster
-click, - click, -click, -click.
I can now dip nine Chicken McNuggets,

give a helping hand to ten
stripping Chippendale hunks,

can ten wonderful
Wonderbra-wearing Wonder Women
of their bras from their breasts divest,
because I now know ten-finger typing.
I can now even, I can now even skate,
in flip-flops.
Perform every trick,

and as I comfortably,
casually with my ten toes
kick ten footbags -bags,
because now I know ten-finger typing.
My girlfriend thinks it's good too.

The massage, tippity-tip-tap-type
chic and slick,

ten love SMSs in just one
second, no stress.

There's nothing now
I can't write in ten seconds

now that I can do ten-finger typing,
flick with ten fingers,

and at the same time
fulfill ten wishes, if you please.

The otherwise dull time here
at TEDxBodensee truly great.
Thank you very much.
(Applause)

Now the circle closes back
to the speaker before me.
I'm also not very decisive.

I always find it very difficult
to make decisions,

especially when it comes 
to choosing texts to present.

I've got two ready, but I'll stick
with just this one.
It's probably a bit longer,
but it rhymes,
and I'm better at those.

There's also a short introduction
to the poem by the author.

It's a poem from my period
of self-discovery.

I'm a little in a phase
of self-discovery regarding my life.
It comes from my blue period.
You'll know the situation perhaps,

when the ink cartridge
in the printer has had it,

and one writes in blue,
because there's still some blue left.
And I was able to print it out again here.
Thank you.

So a self-discovery text,
a touch esoteric,
called "Just Who Am I Really?"
Really,
I'm not fussy.
I don't find fault, squawk, play awkward,
I might harp that I don't carp,
oversighted blighted perhaps,
but mostly I'm calmness personified.
Calm within myself,
I'm tree,
I'm ying,
I'm yang
I'm Zen.

I'm sure of things
as far as a stoner can be.
I know who I am and where I belong.
I listen and keep my end up.

I don't get involved
in ridiculous disputes,

and if a noisy scoffing
match comes looking,
I am mostly inclined to stay silent.
Not rough, tough, arrogant;
just smiling.

Rather than madden,
show my mettle, meddle,
breast the crest of the wave with my best
and stubbornly hold my stand,
I calmly, casually go with the flow
wherever it takes me.
I sink myself like Mahatma Gandhi,

immensely immersed,
in unintimidable thought.

Neither rage nor get bitter,
only passive resistance engage,

because I don't get pettily involved
in every petty thing,
reaching for a weapon

like a boy goatherd
out of 'Heidi' suicide bomber
with an axe.
Dear God, I don't just burst my boiler
and make myself into some great hulk.
I prefer to tie a flower to a pole

that trembles as if
Superman's balls were on fire,

and his boner was sprewing out green
glowing sparks like a bag of kryptonite,
and myself, I relax.
Only sometimes,
sometimes,
I need to ask:
"Who,
yes, who am I?"
"Yes, just who am I?"

"Yes, just who am I really?"
one sometimes still wonders.

Sometimes, when, for example,
the bouncer says,
"Your shoes are okay,

but with that face and beard
you're not coming in."
Sometimes, when the gym teacher says,
"No, Matthias, having your first period

is not sufficient grounds
for skipping gym class."
Just who am I really?
Sometimes,
sometimes, if someone says to you,
"We can still be friends."
Or, "'You're like a big brother to me."
Or, "It's so easy to talk to you."
You want to say, "Yes, I know."

You want to ask, "'Just what's
your relationship like with your brother?"
If you really were my friend,
you'd know that it's just about the sex.
Just who am I really?
Sometimes,
when I say,
"Darling,
I love you,"

and I mean it in all honesty
from deep down,
and she answers,
"Sure, I love you too."
I think to myself:
"Yeah, yeah, lick my ass, you stupid cow."

The last time I'll say
anything like it, anything nice.
Just who am I really?
Sometimes,

when I'm in a hurry threading myself
through the town crowds,

where shopping customers snap
and snip, jumping the queue,
stare in at the window displays,
and really it's just a little overcast,

but all have brought such
giant umbrellas with them
with nasty, ghastly, pointy ends,

with which while shopping,
they prod my temples,

in my cheek carve map
and item list scribbles
as my blood dribbles:
It's then I ask myself,
(Mouths) "Just who am I then, really?"
Sometimes,

when, for example, I go to the social,
stand a ticket in hand from the band,

and after a day, half an eternity,
a quarter of a century,

and it's finally my turn,
the officer then says,

"No, Mr. Brenner,
how many times must I tell you:

There's no training support,
no unemployment benefit,
no immediate annuity,
no European milk subsidies,
neither promotion nor disability pension,

home saving scheme
and no parking ticket refund
to which you're entitled!

In principle, yes, there might be,
but the thing is that was the wrong form.

Come back tomorrow,
it's already half-past four."
There I think, "Just who am I really?"
Sometimes,
sometimes,
- now it gets political, forgive me -

Sometimes when I want to get money
out of the cash machine
in Konstanz, on Marktst√§tte No. 1,

and wonder why money
needs such a palace to live in,

100 square meters in a central location
close to the station,
the bus to uni goes right past the door.
And then

you have unobstructed views
of the lake, while others freeze.

But then the jerks
put the air-conditioning on full blast

so your bladder suddenly
feels ready to burst.
And then before I get my money,

I have to hear that beep
a couple of dozen times:
Input pin number: beep, beep, beep, beep.
Confirm: beep.
Enter amount: beep.
(Laughter)
Amount too high.
(Laughter)

Fuck my ass!
Just who am I really?

Sometimes, when during
the children's church service,
the youth choir jams

with the deacon assistant
and the praise band,

and a top-of-the-gods-hallelujah-
charts-medley-mix rocks,

Singing: "Into the water falls a stone,"
(Imitation of hitting drums)

"quite secretly, quietly, and softly,"
(Imitation of hitting drums)

"and though it is so very small,"
(Imitation of hitting cymbals)
"it produces nonetheless big circles."

I think to myself, 
"What a load of hogwash,"

and I suppose the sods in the sects
will be after the collection?
Just who am I really?
Sometimes,
when I tramp 400 km for a performance
in Bavaria
in the rain,
and the organizer thinks it fortuitous.

"Great, then you've got
almost no traveling expenses.
(Laughter)

But, sorry, your soaking wet
girlfriend can't come in,"

and so far he as he knew,
we weren't on the list,
we should have come earlier.

There's no pay, but here
are three drinks vouchers
for Beck's alcohol-free.
Then I ask myself:
Just who am I really?
No, I'm not really fussy.
I don't find fault, squawk, play awkward,
I might harp that I don't carp,
oversighted blighted perhaps,
but mostly I'm calmness personified.

Well, okay, the anger is sometimes enough
to make wet wood glow white hot.

My hobbies are reading,
cycling, horse riding -
and bomb laying.
(Laughter)
Sometimes.
Thank you, TEDx.
(Applause)
